intro: Haptocarpum, commonly known as the "hooked carpus," is a genus of flowering plants in the family Polygonaceae. These plants are characterized by their unique seed structures, where the seeds are attached to the fruit by a fleshy, hook-like structure called a carpus. Haptocarpum species typically grow in arid and semi-arid regions, adapting to harsh environmental conditions. The plants have simple, alternate leaves and produce small, inconspicuous flowers. Their botanical features make them interesting subjects for study in plant morphology and ecological adaptation.
